channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Covid Live Updates: Biden to Announce New Virus Plan as Omicron Reaches U.S.
item.description: The president’s strategy is expected to include making insurers reimburse the cost of home Covid tests, and tightening rules for international travelers. The first U.S. Omicron case is detected in California.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: As French Election Looms, Candidates Stake Out Tough Positions on Migrants
item.description: With a presidential election looming, French presidential hopefuls are hardening their positions against immigration even as other countries compete for migrant workers.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants waiting to be allocated emergency accommodation by a nonprofit organization in Paris in April.

item.title: ‘Call Me Dog Tag Man’: Pacific Island Is Full of War Relics and Human Remains
item.description: More than 75 years after the Battle of Biak ended, collectors are still finding remnants of the fight, and U.S. authorities are hoping to bring closure to families of soldiers still missing.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat, Richard C. Paddock and Ulet Ifansasti
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A reef on Biak, where a monthslong battle in World War II left relics from the fighting all across the island, now part of Indonesia.

item.title: Pope Francis Heads to Cyprus
item.description: Even as the world focuses on a new coronavirus variant, Francis is embarking on a trip that incorporates longstanding priorities like opening borders and welcoming the destitute.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Cleaning the road next to the U.N.-protected buffer zone in Cyprus ahead of the pope’s visit on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Where is **?’: Fans in China Elude Censors to Talk About Peng Shuai
item.description: She is not the first celebrity to be scrubbed from the internet, but her supporters are finding creative ways to voice their frustration.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Peng Shuai with fans after winning a match during the 2019 W.T.A. Shenzhen Open in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Meghan Wins Legal Battle Against The Mail on Sunday
item.description: An appeals court rejected a bid to force a trial over the duchess’s claim that the tabloid violated her privacy by publishing an anguished letter she sent to her estranged father.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Who, and Where, Is Chinese Tennis Star Peng Shuai?
item.description: China’s censorship of the tennis star’s #MeToo allegations has not been able to silence a chorus of concern for her safety. The Women’s Tennis Association moved to suspend all tournaments in China.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star, at the Australian Open in Melbourne in 2020.

item.title: W.H.O. Scolds Rich Nations for Travel Bans and Booster Shots
item.description: As wealthy countries react to the new Omicron virus variant with travel bans and booster shots, the World Health Organization scolded them, calling the steps ineffective and unfair.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Pedestrians with masks in Paris on Monday.

item.title: How Omicron Could Knock Economic Recovery Off Track
item.description: The latest zigzag in the pandemic has already curtailed travel, but its broader impact on growth and inflation isn’t likely to be known for several weeks.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: “You can’t plan anymore,” said Marisha Wallace, who canceled her holiday trip to Switzerland after officials there imposed a 10-day quarantine.

item.title: E.U. Interpreter Says Greece Expelled Him to Turkey in Migrant Roundup
item.description: The man’s story echoes complaints from human-rights groups that Greek authorities often expel asylum seekers indiscriminately and violently.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Turkish coast guard rescuing a group of Afghan migrants in July who said they were pushed back out to sea by the Greek authorities.

item.title: U.N. Seats Denied, for Now, to Afghanistan’s Taliban and Myanmar’s Junta
item.description: A powerful United Nations committee deferred a decision on applications by the ruling authorities of both countries, widely regarded as pariahs, to replace envoys of the governments they had toppled.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: The 76th United Nations General Assembly in September.

item.title: Putin and West Spar Over NATO’s Military Ties to Ukraine
item.description: Tensions over Ukraine escalated as Russia’s leader demanded “legal guarantees” that the Western military alliance would not expand to the east, a position NATO regards as untenable.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: “The threat on our western borders is, indeed, rising, as we have said multiple times,” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told ambassadors at the Kremlin on Wednesday.

item.title: Vesuvius Victim May Shed Light on Ancient Rome
item.description: Archaeologists found the remains of a person buried at Herculaneum in the eruption of 79 A.D., and hope that with modern technology it will yield fresh insights.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A skeleton found in October is the first victim of the 79 A.D. eruption of Mount Vesuvius to be found in Herculaneum in about 25 years.

item.title: Study Suggests Link Between AstraZeneca Vaccine and Blood Clots
item.description: The findings suggest that the problem is linked to the shot’s use of another, harmless virus to deliver information into human cells.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A woman receiving a dose of the Astra-Zeneca Covid-19 vaccine in Kigali, Rwanda in May.

item.title: Germany Announces Restrictions on Unvaccinated People
item.description: The country is trying to fight a monthlong surge in infections that has been breaking daily case records.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The mostly-empty Augustusstrasse in Dresden, Germany, on Thursday.

item.title: Abortion at the Court
item.description: The Supreme Court seems likely to undermine or overturn Roe v. Wade.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Outside the Supreme Court yesterday.

item.title: Europe Met a Climate Target. But Is It Burning Less Carbon?
item.description: The European Union promised to reduce its emissions 20 percent by 2020. Did it happen?
item.dc:creator: Lois Parshley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: New Biden Covid-19 Plan Will Reimburse At-Home Tests
item.description: The new strategy includes insurance reimbursements for at-home tests and stricter rules for international travelers, as the Omicron variant circulates in more than 30 countries.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Extreme Poverty Has Been Sharply Cut. What Has Changed?
item.description: The U.N. pledged to cut by half the proportion of people living in the worst conditions around the world.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins

item.title: Millions More People Got Access to Clean Water. Can They Drink It?
item.description: The U.N. pledged to halve the proportion of the world without access to clean drinking water by 2015.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: An unfair global response.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at New York’s La Guardia Airport in November.

item.title: Citing Covid-19, Climate and Wars, U.N. Asks Donors for Big Jump in Funding
item.description: The world body said it needed $41 billion to fund humanitarian aid to help 183 million people in 63 countries.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged United Nations vehicle outside the Kabul airport in September. The U.N. said that donor governments needed assurances funding did not empower the Taliban, but stressed the urgent need for aid in Afghanistan.

item.title: Omicron Prompts Swift Reconsideration of Boosters Among Scientists
item.description: Many public health experts were opposed to a boosters-for-all approach. The new variant is changing some minds.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Preparing a dose of the coronavirus vaccine in Houston. Many experts who were initially opposed to boosters now believe that the shots may offer the best immediate defense against the Omicron variant.

item.title: Drought Study on Madagascar Underlines Complexity of Climate
item.description: Low rainfall has caused a humanitarian crisis in Madagascar, but common assumptions about drought didn’t hold up to scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: Digging for water in the dry bed of the Mandrare River in Madagascar in November 2020.

item.title: Surgeon Was First Omicron Case in Israel. Only One Contact Is Sick.
item.description: In the days leading up to his positive test, Elad Maor interacted with about 100 people. So far, only one contact has tested positive.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Dr. Elad Maor

item.title: The Omicron Variant Detected in the United States
item.description: Omicron in California.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Shelby Knowles for The New York Times
item.media:description: The first case of the coronavirus Omicron variant was found in California on Wednesday.

item.title: Turner Prize Goes to Array Collective, an Art Protest Group
item.description: The Belfast-based Array Collective stages carnivalesque interventions at political rallies. Now the group has won Britain’s major art award.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: New E.U. Measures Set to Restrict Asylum Rights at the Belarus Border
item.description: Poland, Latvia and Lithuania could take up to four months to process asylum requests at the border, a delay that aid groups said would leave migrants in unsafe conditions as winter sets in.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrant children on the Belarus border with Poland in November.

item.title: Nigeria Detects Recent Cases of Omicron Variant
item.description: At least 23 countries have reported cases, and that number is likely to grow as more samples are tested, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Ben Ezeamalu
item.media:description: A woman being tested for Covid-19 in Abuja, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: W.H.O. members agree to begin talks on a global pandemic treaty.
item.description: They agreed to set up an intergovernmental negotiating body that is to meet no later than March to begin negotiating an international agreement intended to ensure a more coherent and equitable response to future pandemics.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: The top official of the World Health Organization, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, supports the establishment of a legally binding treaty.

item.title: Germany's Incoming Chancellor Olaf Scholz Backs Vaccine Mandate
item.description: Mainstream German politicians have long dismissed the idea of a vaccine mandate, but are rethinking the issue as cases rise.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A Covid-19 vaccination site in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: Here’s how two flights to the Netherlands could have helped Omicron spread.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A traveler from South Africa was tested for the Omicron variant upon arrival in a special area at the Amsterdam Schiphol Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: U.K. Theatergoers Cover Up Again, After Months Without Masks
item.description: Encouragements to mask up are hardening into mandates. But the new rules are coming from the playhouses, not the government.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Audience members line up outside the Gillian Lynne Theater, where Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Cinderella” is playing.

item.title: Africa, Far Behind on Vaccines
item.description: Every other continent is ahead.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A vaccine clinic in Johannesburg yesterday.

item.title: A Game Designer in Beijing Bought Toy Guns. China Imprisoned Him.
item.description: San Cheng bought toy guns online as props for video game design. Then the police arrived, and he was jailed under China’s strict but messy gun laws.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: San Cheng was arrested for buying toy guns on Alibaba’s Taobao shopping site and detained and imprisoned for three years.

item.title: Trust in Science and Scientists Increased Globally, Poll Finds
item.description: An international survey found that the pandemic had enhanced public faith in researchers and science, up from 2018.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: The number of people who said they had “a lot” of trust in science increased by 10 percentage points in East Asia, Latin America, Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia.

item.title: Vaccine Hesitancy Hurts Covid Fight in Poorer Countries
item.description: Vaccines are finally available in many African countries, but an underfunded public health system has slowed their delivery, and some people there, as well as in South Asia, are wary of taking them.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Max Fisher
item.media:description: Waiting for a vaccination in Johannesburg on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Omicron moves across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Remko De Waal/ANP, via Agence France-Presse

item.title: LeBron James Enters N.B.A.'s Covid Protocols
item.description: Comments from Anthony Davis indicated James has tested positive for the coronavirus, which could keep him out for 10 days.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli
item.media:description: Los Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James has entered the N.B.A.’s Covid-19 protocol.

item.title: Xiomara Castro Edges Closer to Honduran Presidency as Opponent Concedes
item.description: The outcome appeared to be a repudiation of the National Party’s 12-year rule, marked by corruption and the dismantling of democratic institutions.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Xiomara Castro after the closing of the general election on Sunday.

item.title: Omicron Variant, in 20 Nations, Spread Earlier Than Was Known
item.description: With evidence growing that a worrisome new coronavirus variant is highly contagious, health officials issued warnings that vulnerable people should not travel.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A Covid vaccination in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Tuesday.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Vaccine Mandate for Health Workers
item.description: The ruling is a setback for the administration’s effort to require vaccination for hospital and nursing home workers, which had been set to start next week.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Reed Abelson
item.media:description: Protesters rally against vaccine mandates in New York City.

item.title: How 2 Flights to Europe May Have Spurred Spread of New Variant
item.description: A confounding array of Covid rules and lax enforcement of mask wearing may have sent infected passengers on two KLM flights from South Africa on to “who knows where.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Flight restrictions began in South Africa’s O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg last week.

item.title: Josephine Baker Inducted Into French Panthéon
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron hailed the American-born dancer and French resistance fighter as a symbol of unity in a time of sharp division.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The ceremony for Josephine Baker in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: South African Company Nears License to Sell J. & J. Covid Shot Across Africa
item.description: The new agreement makes Aspen Pharmacare the first African company to market a Covid vaccine on the continent. But it stops short of allowing Aspen to make the ingredients in the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Aspen Pharmacare bottled the vaccine under a previous agreement, but a new deal would allow the company to market and distribute the drug as well.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The Omicron variant was in Europe at least a week ago.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A shopping area in Amsterdam was mostly empty on Monday after a coronavirus lockdown went into effect to counteract rising infections and hospital admissions.

item.title: How do you say ‘Omicron’?
item.description: Unlike Alpha, Beta and Delta, the name of the latest known variant is not as straightforward, with some English speakers offering up diverse pronunciations.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Amid Variant Fears, U.K. Discovers Limits to Its Virus Strategy
item.description: Britain’s approach to coronavirus-related restrictions has been looser than other European countries, but the Omicron variant has spurred swift action on mitigation measures.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Commuters at London Bridge station on Tuesday as Britain stepped up its attempts to ward off the Omicron variant.

item.title: England tightens restrictions as more Omicron cases found.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Britain returned to mask mandates on Tuesday, including requiring them for all public transit riders.

item.title: What We Know About the New Covid Variant, Omicron
item.description: Intense research into the new coronavirus variant first identified in southern Africa has just begun. World leaders have urged people not to panic — and to get vaccinated, if they can.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: A woman receiving a Covid shot vaccine at a center in Soweto, South Africa.

item.title: ISIS Fighter Convicted in Death of Enslaved 5-Year-Old Girl
item.description: In a trial held in Germany, the man was sentenced to life in prison for the death of the Yazidi girl, whom he allowed to die of thirst in Falluja, Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Taha Al-J., covering his face with a folder, speaking with his lawyers before he was convicted in the court in Frankfurt on Tuesday.

item.title: Nepal’s embattled chief justice tests positive for the virus, amid broad political disarray.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Protesters in Kathmandu, Nepal, last week demanded the resignation of Cholendra Shumsher Rana as chief justice of Nepal’s Supreme Court over corruption accusations.

item.title: Greece to Fine Older Residents Who Don't Get Vaccinated
item.description: It is the latest European nation to announce restrictions on the unvaccinated, as the country tries to stem a surge.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Monks waited to get a Covid-19 vaccine on Mount Athos, Greece, this month.

item.title: ‘Our Money Has No Value’: Frustration Rises in Turkey at Lira Crisis
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s insistence on directing monetary policy and sticking with low interest rates is draining confidence, economists say.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: A protest in Istanbul last week against worsening economic conditions.

item.title: Covax sets aside vaccine doses for North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pedestrians in Pyongyang, North Korea, this month.

item.title: Éric Zemmour, Far-Right Pundit, Makes French Presidential Run Official
item.description: After months of speculation, Mr. Zemmour, an anti-immigration writer and right-wing television star, said he was running in the presidential elections next year to “save” France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Éric Zemmour, center, in Marseille on Saturday. His previously undeclared campaign for France’s presidency has hit several setbacks in recent days.

item.title: Fighting Racism, Quietly
item.description: The Ahmaud Arbery trial offers lessons for American politics.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: China’s Silence on Peng Shuai Shows Limits of Beijing’s Propaganda
item.description: Officials have struggled to respond to a sexual assault allegation that hits at the heights of its buttoned-up political system.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Within China, the tennis star Peng Shuai’s #MeToo allegations have been systematically purged from social media.
